title: health-workers-should-help-people-with-stis-notify-their-partners
story: Helping people diagnosed with sexually transmitted infections (STI) inform their partners may stem the spread of infection, according to a new draft quality standard by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice).  The new document states that healthcare workers, such as GPs, practice nurses and sexual health consultants, should support people diagnosed with an STI to notify their partners.  &ldquoPartner notification may be undertaken by the healthcare professional or the person diagnosed with an STI, the document states.          Remember that by wearing a condom you're not only protecting yourself, but protecting your partner too. Some STI's have no signs or symptoms. So unless you've recently been checked out &ndash you can't be 100% sure.#UseACondom #PlaySafe pic.twitter/BgeTcK3pYZ          &mdash NHS Mid Essex CCG (@MidEssexCCG) August 18, 2018  It added: &ldquoSupporting people who have been diagnosed with an STI to notify their partners can help to reduce the transmission of STIs.  &ldquoIt can also ensure that their partners are tested, and if necessary treated, as soon as possible to prevent health complications.  Services should ensure that they are prepared to talk to people about &ldquopartner notification and to support people to inform their sexual partners, Nice said.  In 2017, there were 422,147 diagnoses of STIs made in England, it added.  The new quality standard, which has been put out to consultation, aims to improve the care for people accessing sexual health services.  It also states that patients should be seen within 48 hours of requesting an appointment, to reduce the likelihood of them passing on infections and to reduce complications of illness.  A Nice spokesman said: &ldquoIt&rsquos important that partners of people diagnosed with an STI have the opportunity to be tested themselves and if necessary treated, in order to prevent the spread of infections and to reduce their risk of developing health complications.  &ldquoThat&rsquos why our draft standard supports best practice in current sexual health services, that help and support should be provided to people who might otherwise find it difficult to tell their partners about their STI.  Welcoming the new standard,&nbspDr Diana Mansour, vice president for clinical quality for&nbspthe Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH), said:&nbsp&ldquoOne of the recommendations of the draft standard is that people diagnosed with an STI are encouraged to notify their partners.  &ldquoFSRH strongly supports this recommendation so that STI morbidity is reduced in the community.  &ldquoFor healthcare professionals, this means supporting people to contact their own partners or to directly contact, test and treat partners of those with an STI without revealing the patient&rsquos identity.  &ldquoPartner notification can make patients feel uncomfortable. It might pose a strain in relationships new and old or cause embarrassment with more casual partners.  &ldquoHowever, STIs can pose serious health consequences both to the patient and their partners such as infertility and pelvic inflammatory disease.  &ldquoSTI rates are on the rise, with a 20% increase in syphilis cases in 2017 compared to 2016, so we encourage people to visit their local sexual and reproductive health clinic and be tested.

title: activists-urge-catholic-church-to-change-tack-on-lgbt-issues
story: Launching the Equal Future campaign in Dublin to coincide with the beginning of the World Meeting of Families (WMOF), campaigner Tiernan&nbspBrady said he wants to highlight the damage being done to children and young people.  The campaign is the largest global initiative of LGBT groups, including 60 countries worldwide.  Mr Brady said there is a &ldquoclear message that members of the LGBT community were not welcome at the WMOF event in Dublin.  &ldquoWe want to highlight the damage that is being done to children and young people as they grow up thinking that to be LGBT would be wrong,&nbspa disappointment or just bad luck but none of those are true, he said.  &ldquoThe sad truth is there is a clear message they are not welcome at the World Meeting of Families.  &ldquoLGBT looked to have stands and they were&nbspdenied.  &ldquoImages of same-sex families were removed from all the material and I can&rsquot think of a clearer message to show LGBT people you are not part  of this and you are not wanted in here.  &ldquoThat&rsquos not what Catholic people feel and it&rsquos about time the upper management caught up with this.  &ldquoNo child should ever grow up feeling they are less than others if they are or were to discern they are LGBT.  The founder and director of the Equality Campaign said he wants to raise awareness of the damage done to young people when the Synod of Bishops takes place at the Vatican in October.  Mr Brady added: &ldquoThe Synod on Young People is a once-in-a-generation moment for us to shine a light on the role stigma against LGBT in its&nbspvarious forms affects the mental health of children and young people, and has for too long been overlooked.  &ldquoIt is important for the Church to look at this as part of their stated desire to consider situations where young people face exclusion for&nbspsocial or religious reasons.  &ldquoEqual Future 2018 is calling on the Synod on Young People to consider the damage done as a consequence of the Church&rsquos teachings and reconsider its teachings on LGBT, Mr Brady said.  Wednesday&rsquos press conference, held beside the Royal Dublin Society where the WMOF is being held, heard directly from people from around the world and their experiences growing up Catholic and LGBT.  One of the contributors, Eros Shaw, was raised in a traditional Catholic family in China.  &ldquoAs my sexual orientation became more and more apparent, stress from studies and uncertainties about the future also became more intensive, as did my feelings of guilt towards my parents, he said.  &ldquoBut it did not stop my feelings from growing.  &ldquoFrom one day to the next, I struggled in agony.  &ldquoLater I participated the events of China Catholic Rainbow community.  &ldquoIn there I met a great priest friend to be my spiritual director and&nbspfriends who are seem with my case.  &ldquoI feel that I am free from the burden.  &ldquoIt is not my fault that I am gay, I am also beloved by God.  Xorje Olivares lives in New York where he belongs to what its advocates term a &ldquoqueer ministry in a progressive parish.  He grew up along the Texas/Mexico border spending 10 years volunteering as an altar server.  He said:&nbsp&ldquoTowards those later years I already knew I was gay but couldn&rsquot quite figure out God&rsquos plan for me.  &ldquoThe Church was no help, nor was my heavily Latino community, both of which were seemingly unwelcoming to kids like me back then, based off of comments made by certain&nbspauthoritative figures.  On Wednesday evening, members of the LGBT+ community spoke of being welcomed into a parish in central London.  In 2013 LGBT+ Catholics joined the main congregation of Farm Street Church in Mayfair for evening mass.  Since then they contributed to every aspect of liturgical, spiritual and pastoral life of the church.  LGBT+ community member Nick O&rsquoShea said he had been unsure of how to reconcile his beliefs and his sexuality before finding Farm Street.  &ldquoI&rsquom from London and the key thing about London is that it&rsquos almost easier to be gay than be a Catholic, he said.  &ldquoI was lacking a framework for being gay and Catholic and how was I going to live a life that would be pleasing to God.  Then Mr O&rsquoShea said he googled &ldquogay and &ldquomass and &ldquoLondon and learned of the church.  Fr Dominic Robinson said the aim was to create a safe environment for everybody.  &ldquoThis was part of the whole process of what we call opening our doors, Fr Robinson said.  Mr O&rsquoShea called on more parishes to create an inclusive environment for members of the LGBT+ community.  &ldquoIf we&rsquore not careful churches could be empty and what we&rsquove got here is a thriving community of people, Mr O&rsquoShea said.  &ldquoDo I think we need a gay mass on every street corner? No, personally I don&rsquot but I think what we do need is a welcome in every parish for people who no longer find it easy to associate with the Church.

title: liberian-president-george-weah-criticised-for-honouring-arsene-wenger
story: Weah, who was elected president of his country last year, plans to honour the former Arsenal manager and another French soccer coach, Claude Le Roy, at a ceremony on Friday after they both played crucial roles in his career.  Le Roy discovered Weah playing for a club in Cameroon in the late 1980s and recommended him to Wenger, the then coach of Monaco in France.  Wenger took the advice, signed the Liberian who went on to play for Monaco, Paris Saint-Germain and AC Milan, and became the first &ndash and still only &ndash African to win the Fifa world player of the year award in 1995.  Liberian sports minister D. Zeogar Wilson said Wenger will be given the Humane Order of African Redemption with the rank of Knight Grand Commander.  Wenger and Le Roy, the current Togo coach, are both expected to attend Friday&rsquos ceremony, government officials said.  But Darius Dillon, an opposition politician, criticised Weah for using the nation&rsquos highest honour and the office of the president to recognise people who only played a role in his &ldquopersonal life.  &ldquoThe nation&rsquos highest honour cannot be given to somebody who has not done something directly for the country, Mr Dillion said.  Other political opponents have questioned the decision with Emmanuel Gonquoi, of the Economic Freedom Fighters of Liberia, calling it &ldquoa complete waste of time.  Weah is Liberia&rsquos best sportsman ever and the golden years of his career coincided with civil war in Liberia.  Mr Wilson, the sports minister, said he disagreed with the criticism.  &ldquoDuring the heat of the civil war the only good thing that came out of Liberia was George Weah and his soccer prowess, he said.  &ldquoHow can we not honour these guys who made him get where he got?  Weah dedicated his award to Wenger when he was named world player of the year and has said the former Arsenal coach was the most important influence on his career.  He invited Wenger to his inauguration as president in January, although Wenger could not attend.  Wenger has also praised Weah.  &ldquoThe life of this guy is a real film, Wenger said earlier this year. &ldquoIt&rsquos unbelievable. It can make a fantastic film.  The 51-year-old retired from football in 2003 and turned almost immediately to politics, failing in his first attempt to become president of Liberia in 2005.  His victory by a landslide in last year&rsquos election highlighted his inspiring story &mdash he was born in a slum surrounded by swamps on the outskirts of the Liberian capital Monrovia and overcame early hardship to become an international soccer star and then president of his country.

title: corbyn-calls-for-bold-thinking-on-future-of-media
story: Jeremy Corbyn will propose a shake-up of the way the TV licence fee is paid and set as he outlines a raft of suggestions for the BBC and wider media in a speech to the industry.The Labour leader will argue that the licence fee should be modernised for the digital age, with a &ldquofairer and more effective way found to fund the BBC.He will float the idea of introducing a digital licence fee &ndash paid by tech giants or through internet service providers &ndash to supplement the current licence fee, with a view to reducing the cost&nbspfor poorer households and helping the corporation to compete &ldquomore effectively.Mr Corbyn will also propose the creation of a new independent body to set the licence fee and suggest the BBC should be placed on a permanent statutory footing &ldquoto end government control through charter renewal. The Labour leader will air the ideas when he gives the Alternative MacTaggart Lecture at the Edinburgh TV Festival on Thursday, the fourth day of his visit to Scotland.Mr Corbyn is expected to outline his support for the BBC as a publicly&nbspowned, public service broadcaster, but argue it needs to become more free from government influence, more accountable to the public and more representative of the country.Among his suggestions, he will argue for &ldquocomplete transparency over the diversity of the corporation&rsquos workforce with the publication of data including social class, and he will call for the election of some of the BBC board members by staff and licence fee payers.On the licence fee, he will tell the festival: &ldquoIf we want an independent BBC, we should consider setting it free by placing it on a permanent statutory footing, with a new independent body setting the licence fee.&ldquoThe licence fee itself is another potential area for modernisation. In the digital age, we should consider whether a digital licence fee could be a fairer and more effective way to fund the BBC.&ldquoA digital licence fee, supplementing the existing licence fee,&nbspcollected from tech giants and internet service providers, who extract huge wealth from our shared digital space,&nbspcould allow a democratised and more plural BBC to compete far more effectively with the private multinational digital giants like Netflix, Amazon, Google and Facebook.&ldquoThis&nbspcould also&nbsphelp reduce the cost of the licence&nbspfee for poorer households.In a wide-ranging speech on the media as a whole, Mr Corbyn will argue that there is a need for &ldquobold, radical thinking on the future of our media because of &ldquolow levels of public trust and the impact of the digital age.Without major changes, a &ldquofew tech giants and unaccountable billionaires will control huge swathes of our public space and debate, he is expected to say.Mr Corbyn, who once worked on the Newport and Market Drayton Advertiser, will also set out a number of proposals aimed at empowering public interest journalism.These include strengthening Freedom of Information (FOI) rules by ending ministerial vetoes and including private companies delivering public services under the FOI umbrella.Mr Corbyn will say it is unacceptable for corporate executives to &ldquohide behind the excuse of commercial confidentiality when they are providing a public service.&ldquoBut I think we should be more ambitious, he will tell the audience.&ldquoCurrently, ministers can veto FOI releases. On two occasions, this veto has been used to block information about the UK&rsquos decision to pursue military action against Iraq. That can&rsquot be right. We will look at ending the ministerial veto to prevent the Information Commissioner being overruled.The Labour leader is also expected to call for charitable status to be given to some local, investigative and public interest journalism and an independent fund for public interest journalism paid for by tech giants.(function(i,s,o,g,r,a,m){i['GoogleAnalyticsObject']=ri[r]=i[r]||function(){ (i[r].q=i[r].q||[]).push(arguments)},i[r].l=1*new Date()a=s.createElement(o), m=s.getElementsByTagName(o)[0]a.async=1a.src=gm.parentNode.insertBefore(a,m) })(window,document,'script','//www.google-analytics/analytics.js','ga') ga('create', 'UA-72310761-1', 'auto', {'name': 'pacontentapi'}) ga('pacontentapi.set', 'referrer', location.origin) ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension1', 'By Hilary Duncanson, Chief Reporter, Press Association Scotland') ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension2', '0c1ec39f-f9c3-4c84-8643-c1ef7bf21ee0') ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension3', 'paservice:entertainment,paservice:entertainment:tv,paservice:entertainment:uk,paservice:news,paservice:news:uk') ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension6', 'story') ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension7', 'composite') ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension8', null) ga('pacontentapi.set', 'dimension9', null) ga('pacontentapi.send', 'pageview', { 'location': location.href, 'page': (location.pathname + location.search + location.hash), 'title': 'Corbyn calls for \u2018bold\u2019 thinking on future of media'})

title: brexiteer-jacob-rees-mogg-tells-pm-to-chuck-chequers-agreement
story: The backbench Tory and 60 colleagues have signed the letter, which describes the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit Chequers compromise as the &ldquowrong deal for Britain.  It states the UK &ldquodoes not need to do a deal with the EU, but the bloc &ldquoneeds to do a deal with us at all costs.  In the letter, leaked to the , Mr Rees-Mogg says: &ldquoThe Government would be wrong to be fearful of Britain enjoying an independent future. Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals would shackle us to the EU forever.  &ldquoWe would be out of Europe yet still run by Europe. This is why the Prime Minister should &lsquochuck Chequers&rsquo and instead seek a Canada-style free trade agreement with the EU to make the most of the global opportunities that lie ahead.  &ldquoIt is time the Government realised that the EU stands to lose much from no deal being agreed and stopped being cowed by the EU&rsquos threats.  &ldquoIt is time to face down vested interests in the establishment and put democracy first. Yet most of all, it is time &lsquoto chuck Chequers&rsquo, respect the referendum, be out of Europe, take back control and believe in Britain.  The briefing note states the Chequers deal would &ldquoprevent taking back control of our borders, and warns proposals for &ldquoreciprocal mobility arrangements are &ldquodangerously close to free movement.  The intervention comes as the Government prepares to publish papers outlining its planning for a possible no-deal Brexit.  Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is due to give a speech on Thursday to coincide with the release of the first of a raft of papers on more than 80 subjects.  It follows his assurances that EU citizens living in the UK will not be &ldquoturfed out if no deal is agreed with Brussels, as he vowed to &ldquomove swiftly to safeguard their future.  Mr Raab said he is confident of reaching an agreement, but sought to reassure those living in Britain that ministers would act quickly to secure their position if the UK crashes out of the EU.  The Cabinet minister told the BBC: &ldquoWe hugely value the contribution of EU citizens here in the UK and I am confident that in the unlikely eventuality that we don&rsquot have a deal, we will move swiftly to secure their position.  He said it is &ldquoinconceivable we would do anything other than make sure that they are legally in a position where they&rsquore secure to stay.  He added: &ldquoThere&rsquos absolutely no question that we&rsquore going to see EU citizens turfed out &ndash we&rsquove made that clear in the past, I&rsquove made that clear in the past, I&rsquom happy to give that reassurance again today.  Ahead of the publication of the papers, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn insisted there is an &ldquoabsolutely massive difference between the Brexit policies of Labour and the Conservatives.  Speaking in Glasgow, Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoThere&rsquos a massive difference because we are not looking for a no-deal Brexit as many Tory MPs are. We&rsquore not looking to do a deregulatory sweetheart deal with Donald Trump.  &ldquoWe&rsquore looking instead for an economy that invests for the future, gives rights at work, consumer rights, and environmental protection to everybody in our society.  &ldquoThe difference between Labour and the Tories is absolutely massive on this.

title: mcdonalds-to-create-thousands-of-apprenticeships
story: The fast food chain said the move is part of its Youth Opportunity Programme, a new initiative to reduce barriers to employment for two million young people by 2025.  The apprenticeships will provide a combination of workplace training and study, which McDonald&rsquos said will help young people gain &ldquopractical experience, new skills and nationally recognised qualifications while earning.  McDonald&rsquos will offer opportunities across the UK, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy and Switzerland, with plans to expand to other markets in the future.  The group&rsquos chief people officer for the UK, Harriet Hounsell, said: &ldquoAcross the UK, there are many young people struggling to gain the skills and experience they need to succeed in the workplace.  &ldquoBy providing opportunities for young people to continue their education, develop their skills and gain qualifications while they earn, we want to help them take the next steps in their career.  In the UK, McDonald&rsquos said it has helped more than 18,500 qualified apprentices to learn on the job over the past 12 years.  By the end of 2018, the company will also have made 100 places available on its Management Degree Apprenticeship Programme, a two- to five-year apprenticeship developed in partnership with Manchester politan University.  McDonald&rsquos cited statistics from the European Commission which show that nearly 5.5 million of Europe&rsquos young people are not in employment, education or training.

title: parents-anxiety-over-school-tests-blamed-on-information-vacuum
story: The warning comes after a national campaign was launched urging parents to opt children out of the literacy and numeracy assessments in P1.  The tests are supposed to help teachers assess the academic levels pupils have achieved when they first come to school.  They are then used to judge progress throughout their school career with further testing in P4, P7 and S3.  However, critics argue testing five-year-olds is meaningless because levels of maturity are so different.  There have also been concerns that pupils have found the assessments stressful - partly in cases where whole classes have sat the tests against government guidance.  Joanna Murphy, chair of the National Parent Forum of Scotland (NPFS), praised the information from the assessments.  In a letter to The Herald she said: &ldquoI have seen sample results ... and the information available to teachers is exceptional.  &ldquoIt provides details of a child&rsquos specific skills, knowledge and understanding, which enhances the teacher&rsquos judgement.  However, Ms Murphy said a full understanding of the roll-out and purpose of the assessments had never been passed on to parents.  The NPFS previously suggested that letters should be sent to all P1 parents to ensure they fully understood the Scottish National Standardised Assessments.  She said: &ldquoThey [Scottish Government] believed it would result in unnecessary profile raising, but as we made clear, and we are now seeing, when there is a vacuum of information it allows for fear and anxiety to spread.  &ldquoWhat is of most concern is that parents are not getting the clear, balanced information they need to be able to decide whether assessment is right for their child.  &ldquoThis issue is wider than the standardised assessments, it is about a repeated lack of good direct communication from schools, local authorities and Scottish Government to parents.  Tavish Scott, education spokesman for the Scottish Liberal Democrats, accused the government of &ldquodeliberately confusing parents over their right to withdraw children from national testing.  Advice on whether pupils can opt out has been conflicting with some internal documents suggesting the test are not compulsory.  The most recent government statement says there is no formal legal right to withdraw - because the tests themselves are not statutory - but suggests parent should talk to their school if they want to opt out.  John Swinney, the Deputy First Minister, welcomed the view that standardised assessments could provide &ldquoexceptional information.  He added: &ldquoParent organisations worked with the Scottish Government to co-produce information leaflets for parents, carers and teachers about the standardised assessments which were sent to all schools last summer.  &ldquoWe expect schools to communicate effectively with parents, and parents can talk to their child&rsquos school at any time.  &ldquoFollowing a review of the first year of assessments, we will shortly set out changes and enhancements to the system for this year, including enhanced communication with parents.  First Minister Nicola Sturgeon introduced the assessments as a response to concerns over falling standards of literacy and numeracy and a lack of consistent data across the country. However, critics claim they are too stressful for the youngest pupils.

title: first-womens-football-game-in-europe-was-played-in-carstairs
story: A minister's objection to women joining in a kickabout on a Sunday in Carstairs, Lanarkshire, in 1628, saw players branded 'insolent'.  The Rev John Lindsay condemned women and men playing football on the Sabbath as it was expected to be a religious day devoted to solemn reflection and worship.  A church document dated August 21, 1628, revealed: "Mr John Lindsay, minister at Carstairs, having regretted the break of the Sabbath by the insolent behaviour of men and women in footballing, dancing and Barley Breaks, ordains every Brother (Minister) to labour to restrain the foresaid insolence and break of Sabbath, and to that effect to make intimation thereof into their several kirks next Sabbath day."  Experts believe the venue for the match was Carstairs' village green where the village's church originally stood.  The find has been hailed by politicians and academics on the 390th anniversary of the letter being penned.  Aileen Campbell,&nbspMSP for Clydesdale, said: "As Clydesdale&rsquos MSP, I am thrilled that Carstairs in my constituency is the location of the first recorded women&rsquos football game in Europe.  "It is therefore fitting to be welcoming the game 'home' as we promote women&rsquos football and encourage women and girls to take up sport.  "As a football fan, I am delighted to see women&rsquos football continue to grow and develop. This is a sport which has an illustrious and very local history, and I congratulate everyone who has helped bring this commemoration together."  Robert Craig, chair of the Scottish Football Museum, said: "Scotland is well-known and respected for its long and pioneering history in the world of men&rsquos football.  "But perhaps less well known is the rich and longstanding history of women&rsquos football in Scotland.  "Women&rsquos football is often regarded as a relatively new sport, so we are delighted to highlight this written evidence tracing its roots back to the seventeenth century."  A seminar on women&rsquos football is set to take place at Hampden Park next March.  Vivienne MacLaren, of Scottish Women&rsquos Football, said: "Scotland has a proud history within the women&rsquos game and we are delighted to acknowledge that women&rsquos football has been present in Scotland for 390 years, far longer than most people would imagine.  "As custodians of women&rsquos football in Scotland we also welcome the launch of the first seminar to be held to share ideas and develop the game in Scotland."  Britain's first recorded international women's football match was played in Edinburgh in May 1881.  A team representing Scotland beat one from England 3-0  In 1894, medical professionals called for girls and women to be banned completely from playing.  The British Ladies Football Club was formed in 1895 with Dumfries aristocrat Lady Florence Dixie as its patron.

title: dont-mention-god-in-tourism-drive-snp-ministers-told
story: The blunt advice "Don&rsquot mention God in the US" was given to the government as it was developing its &pound6m Scotland is Now campaign, which launched in April.  It followed an apparently innocuous reference to Scotland&rsquos role in the hunt for the elusive Higgs Boson, or &ldquoGod particle, named after the Edinburgh-based physicist Sir Peter Higgs.  The phrase was dropped after a blistering report from a Brighton-based firm of media consultants, which was published yesterday on the Scottish Government website.  There was also brutal criticism of a boast in the draft campaign that Scotland had produced arguably the best James Bond in Sir Sean Connery.  That was dismissed as &ldquoobtuse and &ldquofacile when compared to another boast about Scotland helping to develop the world&rsquos first cancer vaccine.  &ldquoHow is that an achievement? was the summary of the &ldquobest 007 claim.  Ministers were also told images of children could deter potential visitors.  A list of &ldquodon&rsquots included &ldquochildren put people off (avoid on holiday), and while a shot of a castle was considered essential, the advice declared &ldquochildren can be a negative.  Golf was also &ldquopolarising, with &ldquominority appeal, and an over-familiar image of Scotland.  The 110-page &ldquoinsight findings were released under Freedom of Information law.  Produced by Lucid People (UK) Ltd, they gave feedback and advice on an early version of the promotional campaign now being aimed at in North America, London and China.  A joint project by ministers, VisitScotland, Universities Scotland and Scottish Development International, the aim was to show Scotland as a great place to visit, study, work and invest.  The original plan was also to &ldquokick-start an advocacy-driven movement that would lead people round the world to view Scotland &ldquoas a great brand.  However the media consultants said large parts of the draft campaign, which initially considered using the slogan &ldquoScotland&rsquos Calling or &ldquoGo Scotland, were a duds.  Messages aimed at visitors were the most successful, followed by those for businesses.  But the research found many people were left &ldquoconfused, disengaged and/or irritated by efforts to build a Scottish &ldquobrand, including a film featuring Austin Powers star Mike Myers.  Out of character, Mr Myers was &ldquonot recognised by many of those on whom the material was tested, and the film left people struggling to understand it, &ldquoeven after explanation.  The &lsquobrand&rsquo material was &ldquounclear, &ldquoself-congratulatory and too focused on the past.  When appealing to investors, ministers were advised to &ldquoavoid too many &lsquohigh brow&rsquo science refs and not &ldquoassume US target will be able to distinguish British (even European) accents.  The June 2017 findings were used to hone the campaign ahead of its launch this year, when Nicola Sturgeon declared it would &ldquoinspire people to be part of Scotland&rsquos future.  The report also revealed some of the image problems facing Scotland.  Among the starting perceptions in the US were &ldquocastles and fog and &ldquonothing to do.  Meanwhile one UK person tested said: &ldquoScotland is dry. Not literally but emotionally. Sitting in a pub. Walking and hiking. Going and seeing a castle and getting drunk.  Another UK contributor said: &ldquoGrey and rainy. Windy and miserable. And not much culture.  A Scottish Government spokesperson said: "Scotland is Now is a successful campaign to stimulate economic growth and position Scotland as a bold and positive country that is progressive, pioneering and inclusive.  &ldquoAs with all our campaigns, we worked with partners on many ideas and concepts to ensure a successful launch. This particular testing was undertaken at a very early stage, and many further iterations of the campaign followed with a variety of ideas coming and going as the final concept crystallised.

title: edinburgh-festival-fringe-eyes-the-mound-for-a-revamp-in-2019
story: The performances on the Mound in central Edinburgh - a public space which is annually thronged with tourists and festival goers enjoying jugglers, acrobats, singers, actors and other artists - is to be re-organised for next year's festival.  The area this year has often been and packed with people, both audiences and people trying to walk, and yesterday at the Annual General Meeting of the Fringe Society, concern was raised about the conditions of the space during the festival.  The chief executive of the Fringe, Shona McCarthy, said the Mound, a man-made hill that connects the Old and the New Towns, surmounted by the Scottish National Gallery and the RSA building, would be the next public space to be revamped after significant changes were made to the Royal Mile artist performance this year.  However, how the changes will be implemented will depend on the major revamp to the National Gallery, which the National Galleries of Scotland are currently planning.  She said: "This year we have completely reviewed the High Street, and how it looks...and I think the new stages, the accessibility platforms have been really well received.  "I agree there is still work to be done on The Mound, and next year that will be a priority for us.  "We need to reconsider how we manage the street performers on the Mound, there are bottlenecks, there are places that could work better for us."  A street performer at the AGM, Silver, said that the space was now cramped and "a disaster".  He blamed the National Galleries of Scotland for, several years ago, erecting railings outside the gallery buildings, reducing the amount of room, including steps, for the public to gather on.  "Picture families sitting on those steps," he said.  The area at the bottom of the Playfair Steps, lined on one side by stalls, is often extremely difficult to navigate, he added.  He added: "Think about this fence, it has destroyed the area, if you want to make it better, get rid of that."  A spokeswoman for the Fringe said that the changes did not mean the removal of street performers, but a performance and facility revamp similar to the one experienced on the Royal Mile.  There has been much debate this summer about the use of public space in Edinburgh during the festival.  The erection of black boards on Princes Street to shield the view of the Summer Sessions gigs in Princes Street Gardens led to controversy and their partial removal.  Oliver Davies, head of marketing at the Fringe, added: "We've done a lot of work on the High Street this year, one of the reasons we did not extend that to the Mound is that the National Galleries of Scotland have a long standing application to redevelop their footprint on the Mound.  "We felt it was right to hold off, and we are still not sure what that impact might be, it will affect that space to some extent."  A spokesman for the National Galleries of Scotland said that the railings outside the National Gallery, while not always present, were part of its listed status.  The detail of the new revamp of the gallery will be revealed in the near future, he noted.

title: nicola-sturgeon-to-welcome-delegates-to-international-culture-summit
story: The fourth Edinburgh International Culture Summit will run from Wednesday to Friday at the Scottish Parliament.  First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will be among those welcoming delegates at an opening event later, which takes place during the height of the Edinburgh festival season.          If you could ask 3 questions at the #EdCultureSummit &ndash who would they be directed at and what would they be? https://t.co/My0oWQEIYU pic.twitter/nT6oVzRDNN          &mdash Culture Summit (@CultureSummit) August 13, 2018  Prime Minister Theresa May is to make a video address to the gathering, which this year makes &ldquoconnecting peoples and places its central theme.  Three key issues to be explored will be culture and wellbeing, culture in a networked world and culture and investment.  Speakers from as far afield as the US, India, Romania, Saudi Arabia and Singapore are some of those expected to address the event over the coming days.  Among those addressing the summit will be the former governor-general of New Zealand Sir Jerry Mateparae, who will talk about the contribution of Maori culture, while Dr Catarina Vaz Pinto, a councillor of culture in Portugal, will focus on maintaining a balance between protecting historic culture and regenerating spaces.  The summit is a collaboration between the Scottish and UK governments, the British Council, Edinburgh International Festival and Scottish Parliament, and is delivered by the Edinburgh International Culture Summit Foundation.

title: rooms-with-beer-on-tap-brewdog-opens-hotel-in-us
story: Named the DogHouse, it is located on the site of its brewery in Columbus, Ohio, and has beer taps in each room.  A crowdfunding drive raised more than 300,000 US dollars (&pound233,000) for the project and those who contributed were given first access to booking rooms at the hotel before it opened to the public.  The hotel has 32 rooms and BrewDog said guests will be able to watch beer being made from rooms overlooking the brewery.  A second DogHouse hotel is under construction at BrewDog&rsquos headquarters in Ellon, Aberdeenshire, due to open next year.  Co-founder James Watt said: &ldquoFor many beer fans, the idea of a beer hotel was just a pipe-dream. A beer utopia that was never thought possible. Until now. Thanks to the backing of our global community of beer evangelists, we&rsquove been hard at work to make that dream a reality.  BrewDog US chief executive Tanisha Robinson said: &ldquoThe DogHouse is truly a hotel like no other.  &ldquoWith the help of our passionate community, we have created a must-visit destination for craft beer fans around the world.  &ldquoWe never shy away from ambitious tasks at BrewDog and the creation of the DogHouse is no exception. We have pushed the boundaries of what modern hospitality can be and, in doing so, have created an unrivalled beery experience.  &ldquoWe hope this inspires brewers and hoteliers to continue innovating and expanding the possibilities of what can be done with beer.

title: first-beano-annual-from-1939-to-be-sold-at-auction
story: The 1940 Beano Book was published around the outbreak of the Second World War in 1939, a year after the weekly comic was first published by Dundee-based DC Thomson in July 1938.  It is the first of 79 Beano annuals published to date and features comic strips, stories and illustrations &ndash but does not include mischief-maker Dennis the Menace, who made his first appearance in 1951.  His pet dog Gnasher was introduced in 1968.  The annual is to go under the hammer at Keys Fine Art Auctioneers in Aylsham, Norfolk and is expected to sell for between &pound1,200 and &pound1,500.  Robert Henshilwood, head of books for Keys, said: &ldquoBeano is the archetypal kids&rsquo comic, and it has been published without a break for 80 years.  &ldquoIt is very rare to see a copy of the first ever Beano Annual, especially in such good condition, and we are expecting a lot of interest from collectors from right across the UK and beyond.  He said the annual had a small print run.  It is one of a number of comics and children&rsquos books to be auctioned at the two-day book sale at Keys, which takes place on Thursday August 30 and Friday August 31.  The Beano annual will be auctioned on the first day of the sale, which also includes a series of Rupert the Bear annuals dating from the 1930s onwards.  According to DC Thomson, the word Beano is a shortened version of bean feast, meaning a rowdy jollification.  The comic was reduced to 12 pages per fortnight during the Second World War due to paper shortages, and after the conflict the Beano editor&rsquos name was discovered on a Nazi assassination list for &ldquogross disrespect.

title: gers-scotlands-finances-in-first-year-of-independence-would-have-been-worse-than-previously-thought
story: The annual Government Expenditure and Revenue Scotland (GERS) figures showed a deficit of &pound13.4bn or 7.9 per cent of GDP in 2017/18.  The UK deficit was 1.9 per cent of GDP in the same year.  Public spending in Scotland was a record &pound1576 higher per head than in the rest of the UK thanks to a cross-border subsidy from the Treasury.  The Scottish Tories said the &lsquoblack hole&rsquo in the nation&rsquos finances showed why the SNP should drop any plans for another independence referendum.  The GERS figures showed Scotland&rsquos finances would have been in an even worse state than previously thought in the first year of independence had there been a Yes vote in 2014.  Last year, GERS said the deficit had been &pound13.3bn, or 8.3 per cent of GDP, in 2016/17.  However these have now been revised to &pound14.5bn and 8.9 per cent of GDP.  The White Paper on independence launched by Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond forecast a manageable deficit of between &pound2.7bn to &pound5.5bn, or 1.6 to 3.2 per cent of GDP.  The difference was due to the oil price slump after the 2014 referendum.  The GERS figures also showed a record &lsquoUnion dividend&rsquo of &pound1982 in 2016/17 after revisions compared to &pound1882 in 2017/18 and &pound952 in 2013/14.  This is the difference between how much Scotland contributed per head to the Exchequer and received back in public spending.  In 2017/18, Scotland&rsquos per capita tax revenue was &pound306 lower than the UK level and spending was &pound1576 higher.  Just seven years ago, Scotland was a net contributor to the Treasury, at &pound200 per head.  The new data did however show a marked upturn in Scotland&rsquos geographical share of revenue from the North Sea, which was up from &pound266m in 2016/17 to &pound1.3bn.  Overall, Scotland generated 8 per cent of UK revenue last year, had 9.3 per cent of public spending, and accounted for 34 per cent of the UK&rsquos &pound39.3bn deficit.  Ms Sturgeon said the figures showed the Scottish economy was in a &ldquostate of recovery, but Brexit remained a &ldquoreal and present danger.  She highlighted growth in the onshore economy in Scotland had been faster than in the UK.  The SNP&rsquos recent Growth Commission, its revised economic blueprint for independence, envisaged a year one deficit of around 8.3 per cent, more than in 2017/18.  &ldquoThat would suggest the trajectory in more positive in reality than the Growth Commission assumed, Ms Sturgeon said.  To the dismay of many on the left of the independence movement, the Commission proposed keeping a tight rein on public spending to halve the deficit over 10 years.  Ms Sturgeon said cutting the deficit was important, but not if it meant austerity.  She said: &ldquoFiscal rules should not become counter-productive. So if actually what the economy needs is stimulus to get the economy growing faster, that&rsquos what should take priority. The Growth Commission was an explicit rejection of the kind of austerity economics we have seen in recent years.  She said the 3 per cent deficit target in the Commission was &ldquoa reasonable one, but added it was important not to become &ldquoso fixated on that that it becomes counterproductive.  Asked if the &pound1576 extra public spending per head would look fair to voters south of the border, she said it was &ldquomore than fair given the history of North Sea oil receipts.  Ms Sturgeon refused to apologise for the even wider gap between the official figures for the putative first year of independence and those in the White Paper.  She said: &ldquoI would defy anybody to say that they foresaw what happened in the North Sea and oil revenues. That&rsquos what changed the projections.  &ldquoWhat we see here today is an improving position, as oil improves and as our onshore [economy] improves. Don&rsquot lose sight of the fact that onshore revenues excluding oil and gas are up by &pound2bn. That is faster growth in onshore revenues than UK growth in onshore revenues in the same year.  &ldquoWe have a Scottish economy that has had a difficult time in the last few years because of the position in oil. Notwithstanding that we have had strong onshore growth and we see that picture continuing here.  Finance Secretary Derek Mackay added: "The latest economic data points to an improving picture in Scotland. Our economy grew twice as fast as the UK in the most recent quarter, while unemployment remains close to its record low and confidence is returning to the oil and gas sector.  "Overall revenue in Scotland reaching &pound60bn for the first time ever, underlining the fact that we have a productive and growing economy, despite the UK Government's London centric economic policies.  "Meanwhile, Scottish exports of goods have increased by 12 per cent over the past year - the fastest rate of growth of any nation in the UK - with huge potential for further expansion in key overseas markets."  Scottish Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: &ldquoIf Nicola Sturgeon wants to continue her threat of second referendum, she has to explain where she would find &pound13bn to fill this deficit.  &ldquoAssuming that can&rsquot be done, the prospect of another divisive and unwelcome vote must be removed for good so Scotland can focus on what really matters.  &ldquoYet again, the union dividend has been made clear.  &ldquoBy being part of the UK, Scotland received an extra &pound1576 for every man, woman and child last year above the UK average. For a family of four, that&rsquos more than &pound6000 in additional public spending.  &ldquoIf Scotland was to be ripped out the UK, this spending would be slashed drastically, meaning schools, hospitals and infrastructure would be hit.  &ldquoAny Scottish Government would also have to massively increase taxes and borrowing to help make up the difference, something the hardworking public simply wouldn&rsquot accept.  &ldquoAnd while Scotland&rsquos finances improved slightly on the whole last year, the rest of the UK&rsquos have done even better, meaning the gap is now bigger. Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: &ldquoPeople across Scotland are sick and tired of austerity &ndash and these figures show that the SNP&rsquos plans for independence would mean unprecedented levels of austerity for Scotland.  &ldquoThe SNP&rsquos plan to close Scotland&rsquos deficit is a cuts commission &ndash a vision which protects the interests of big corporations and the privileged few instead of our vital public services.  &ldquoThe dividing line in Scotland is now between Labour&rsquos plan to invest and build an economy that works for the many, not the few, or further austerity with the SNP and the Tories.  Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: &ldquoThese numbers are another cruel blow to the Nationalists, coming from their own government.  &ldquoIt adds to the misery set out in the SNP's Growth Commission.  &ldquoWhichever way you look at it, under nationalist plans all the good things we all want to do in Scotland would be under threat because of funding cuts. Investing in people through education and mental health would be harder under independence.  Scottish Green MSP Patrick Harvie added: &ldquoHere we have another reminder that the Scottish economy is still too focussed on oil and gas extraction instead of making the needed transition to clean and sustainable renewable sources of energy.  &ldquoWhile other parties use this annual publication as justification for how Scotland couldn&rsquot be a small, successful independent country, or how great the SNP government thinks it is they&rsquod do well to remember that both our prosperity and our climate depends on moving to a clean economy.  Professor Graeme Roy, director of the Fraser of Allander think tank, said: &ldquoGERS takes the current constitutional settlement as given.  &ldquoIf the very purpose of independence is to take different choices about the type of economy and society that we live in, then a set of accounts based upon the world today will tell us little about the long-term finances of an independent Scotland.  &ldquoBut GERS does provide a pretty accurate picture of where Scotland is in 2018. So in doing so, today&rsquos numbers set the starting point for a discussion about the immediate choices and challenges that need to be addressed by those advocating new fiscal arrangements.  Mike Tholen of&nbspOil &amp Gas UK&nbspsaid the GERS data showed a "striking transformation" of the UK oil and gas industry since the downturn.  He said: "Improvements to operational efficiency, careful management of costs and a stablefiscal regime have ensured it is better placed to weather volatility in international oil markets. This golden formula must now be maintained as we look to maximise economic recovery.
